by Jessica Mandel
Zbigniew Brzezinski, former
national security advisor to
President Carter, and Sol
Linowitz, former advisor for
Middle East Negotiations during the Carter administration,

Johns Hopkins Board of Trustees, will speak on November

American foreign policy in the
Middle East.

American foreign policy in
Latin America.

general," according to Rubery.

financial prospects. "We have
raised $4,000, not $17,000, but
there is still fundraising in progress," said Rubery.

Student Council Furniture
The Student Council is buying new furniture for its office. For no reason at all.
Originally, Council President Maureen
Freed proposed that a new secretarial desk,
10 stacking chairs, two executive desk chairs,
and a small conference table should be purchased for $1000. And the reason for buying the 14 pieces of furniture would be to
make the office functional. Again.
Last year's Council, however, never complained that their office wasn't functional.
And thus never requested new furniture.
So. what were Freed's reasons for the proposed $1000 expenditure?
The secretarial desk is too small; it only
has enough room for a typewriter. The present executive desk chair is broken. There
aren't enough chairs. And there isn't a small
conference table in the office, only a long
table where the stencil machine and the
Gestetner rest.
Secretarial work, especially Council secretarial work, doesn't necessarily have to be
done at the secretarial desk.
The executive desk chair can be repaired.

No more stacking chairs are needed on
campus.
And a conference table just isn't necessary. Last year, a conference room was added to the SAC office to provide student
groups and Council committees with a functional meeting area.
At the meeting, Freed said there was an
advantage to buying the equipment. "They
will deliver it within 72 hours. Let's do it
once and do it right."
After four votes(one for each type of furniture), the Council decided upon the secretarial desk and the two executive chairs,
which could have been purchased at an auction or a government surplus if Freed didn't
want the furniture immediately.
Council will now have to defend their $470
purchase, which may annoy several SAC
groups whose budgets were decreased this
year due to an overall cut in the SAC budget.
Moreover, arguments concerning the 14
pieces of furniture wasted most of Wednesday night's Council meeting, which could've

Dlack and White
To the Editor:
The tumult, rhetorical flourishes, and posturing connected
with the primary election have
come to a blessed end. Mayor
William Donald Shaefer has
won clearly and decisively.
However, the pattern of victory, to a substantial degree,
with the inexplicable exception
of Mayor Schaefer, followed a

time-honored and ancient pattern: whites voted for whites;
blacks voted for black and
whites.
Judge William H. Murphy
and Delegate John Douglass,
who waged high level and exemplary campaigns, were denied
victory in a majority black city.
The essential reason for their losing, as is universally known
across the city and state, is not
that they were not eminently
qualified, progressive and
humane, but that a majority of
their fellow black Baltimoreans
rejected them.
This rejection, I believe, will
have both short-run and longrun calamitous consequences in
terms of the collective black
psyche, unity and social cohesion. Equally disquieting, the
majority black population of
Baltimore has signaled to the
white minority population an acquiescence in continued socio-

economic and political subordination. Minority white control,
in fact, for the next four years
will remain firmly and solidly in
place.
The forward movement for
black self-reject (sic), self-esteem,
equal power sharing and solidarity has been dealt a shattering
blow.
